documentType: Bureau of Prisons intake screening and risk assessment
summary: This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological intake screening and risk assessment forms for Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 8, 2019, the day of his court proceeding. It includes mental health evaluation, risk assessment for sexual abusiveness, and a suicide risk consultation note due to his high-profile case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the psychological intake screening and risk assessment at MCC-NY, incarcerated for sex trafficking, denies mental health history and sexual abuse victimization.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: Conducted the initial intake evaluation and risk assessment of Epstein, noted as PsyD/PhD provider.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: Consulted with Dr. from Central Office regarding Epstein's suicide risk factors and issued instructions for monitoring upon his return from court.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: Consulted with the facility's Chief Psychologist regarding Epstein's suicide risk assessment.

connections.description: Clinical psychologist conducted intake screening and risk assessment of inmate Epstein.
Chief psychologist consulted with Central Office psychologist regarding Epstein's suicide risk.

events.title: Epstein Psychological Intake Screening
events.description: Bureau of Prisons psychology services conducts initial intake evaluation and risk assessment for sexual abusiveness on Jeffrey Epstein at MCC-NY.

events.title: Court Proceeding
events.description: Epstein attends court proceeding that could potentially give him "bad news regarding his legal situation," prompting suicide risk concerns.

events.title: Suicide Risk Consultation
events.description: Chief psychologist consults with Central Office regarding Epstein's suicide risk factors and orders monitoring upon his return from court.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was assessed as having no current mental health symptoms, no suicidal ideation, and meeting criteria for the lowest mental health care level (CARE1-MH).

Epstein was identified as being at risk for sexual abusiveness due to prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community and prior violent offense convictions, but was judged to be at 'Low Risk of Abusiveness' at the facility.

Psychology staff expressed concern about suicide risk factors including Epstein's high-profile case, media attention, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and potential bad news from his court proceeding.
Epstein denied any history of being a victim of physical or sexual abuse, despite being charged with sex trafficking and previously with prostitution.
Instructions were given for staff to immediately notify psychology department when Epstein returned from court and to place him on watch status if he returned after hours.
